data.text: The Portland Design Works Bindle Rack: Pros/Cons?
has anyone used / tested the Portland Design Works “Bindle” rack? pros? cons? thanks…
This looks neat
data.author: Andrew Huff

data.text: I think it may be discontinued, but I have one. just not sure it will hold up in the long haul…
data.author: Josh Levine

data.text: I had one. The bolts rusted out and the rack part became very stiff to move. I lubricated it, but should have had stainless hardware. Great idea, poor execution
data.author: Harry Meyer

data.text: i have one coupled with a revelate terrapin bag. the two work nicely together. My only concern is that the seatpost bracket is threaded aluminum which requires significant torque and may wear out with constant install/uninstalls on my bike.
data.author: Mark Laken

data.text: I have been using one for a few years and it works great. In my case, I got I to have more clearance between my tailbag and rear tire, especially in rough terrain. It has the added benefit of eliminating sway. I haven't had any issues with the aluminum clamp, but am very aware of the amount of torque I apply. The only issue I've had is the buckles haven't held up great, but I think PDW addressed this in newer models.
data.author: James D. Cooper

data.text: I have used one as well on my commuter. It's a bit fiddly to install and get just right. I will agree the seat post mount needs a redesign but the overall idea of the rack is good it just needs better execution.
data.author: Travis Winkler

data.text: I'm satisfied with mine. Stays pretty solid. If it weren't for the price I would have rather had the Mr Fusion as the concept is the same but possibly executed better.
data.author: Kurt Pitts

data.text: I ❤️ mine!
data.author: Martin Jahr

data.text: Love mine to, and the reason I bought it was that I want to shred the trails with bags as hard as I do without them. Also user it with the Terapin bag.
data.author: Marco Laffra

data.text: Not a fan by looking at it.. 1. It would definitely wiggle 2. It can damage your seatpost
data.author: James Pang

data.text: ....all weights were at the mercy of these supporting straps.
data.author: Man Hernaez

data.text: Which is absolutely no different to any saddle pack..
data.author: Adam Macer

data.text: I have one. I threw out the straps that came with it immediately because they were useless. I fasten the rack to the seat with a ratchet strap. Together they function like a big clamp to grip a dry sack. I like it. I’ll keep using it.
data.author: Bjorn Leiren

data.text: Have you considered a Wayward Louise dry bag harness? I love mine - it’s rock solid and really easy on the seat post. It’s replaced my saddlepack and Woho antisway thingy.
data.author: Scott Bakker

data.text: Better VAPCYCLING
data.author: Davide Calegaro

data.text: I like it. Im on a small frame bike and never have enough gear in the seat bag to completely fill a midsize bag. Made a custom drybag for it. No more tire rub, no tightening straps constantly, no bag waggle.
data.author: Morgan Bailey

data.text: Friend used one on Baja divide and it snapped from fatigue. Would probably work fine on paved roads but not for bumpy bikepacking
data.author: Nick Quine

data.text: I have one and it helps Solve the small frame insufficient tire clearance problem. Carbon seat posts can be protected with a piece of inner tube.
data.author: Brian Morin

data.text: I have been using one for about 5 years. Really excellent. super secure, no sway, drybag goes on and off really quickly. Compared to my friends with seat packs from some other big brands, this wins hands down in my book.
data.author: Adie Mitchell

data.text: I’ve bought a pannier rack… sick of the rear bag pulling my saddle taught… the rack actually weighs less than the restrap saddle bag and I then bought a 14ltr dry bag which fits everything and reduces what I have on my bars “more aero”
data.author: Lee Joseph Elliott

data.text: Returned mine. Great in theory, but straps are lazily designed, and though others have reported otherwise, the sway was terrible for me
data.author: Dominic Castro-Wehr
